qa_list.question: What is the combined mission of Carnegie Mellon University's libraries?
qa_list.answer: The combined mission of Carnegie Mellon University's libraries, including the Mellon Library and Sorrells Library, is to provide access and help for graduate students in finding information needed, teaching them how to evaluate available information, and using reliable sources.

qa_list.question: What services does Computing Services develop and maintain at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Computing Services at Cyert Hall – Room 285 develops, maintains, and supports the computing infrastructure for students, faculty members, and staff members. This includes campus wired and wireless networks, public computer labs or 'clusters', cable television and telephone services, computing-related documentation, and support through the Help Center.

qa_list.question: What resources does the Graduate Student Assembly website provide for spouses, domestic partners, and families of graduate students?
qa_list.answer: The Graduate Student Assembly website provides a resource page for spouses, domestic partners, and families of graduate students. This includes The Student Parent Association, new mother rooms, and links to resources around campus and the Pittsburgh area.

qa_list.question: What is the location of Computing Services at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Computing Services is located in Cyert Hall – Room 285.

qa_list.question: How can students contact the Help Center for computing-related assistance at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Students can email the Help Center at it-help@cmu.edu or call 412-268-4357 (HELP) with questions and for assistance.

qa_list.question: What is the URL of the resource page maintained by the Graduate Student Assembly website for spouses, domestic partners, and families of graduate students?
qa_list.answer: https://www.cmu.edu/stugov/gsa/Resources-for-Graduate-Students/index.html

qa_list.question: What services does Computing Services provide for graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Computing Services provides computing infrastructure support, including campus wired and wireless networks, public computer labs or 'clusters', cable television and telephone services, computing-related documentation, and support through the Help Center.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Carnegie Mellon University Libraries' digital resources and services?
qa_list.answer: The libraries’ digital resources and services, including off-campus/wireless access to databases and e-journals, offer online access for graduate students.

qa_list.question: What are the two neighboring libraries open to Carnegie Mellon graduate students?
qa_list.answer: The two neighboring libraries open to Carnegie Mellon graduate students are Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh and University of Pittsburgh Libraries.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the resource page maintained by the Graduate Student Assembly?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the resource page maintained by the Graduate Student Assembly is to provide resources for spouses, domestic partners and families of graduate students.

qa_list.question: Who can access Affiliate ID Cards at Carnegie Mellon’s campus?
qa_list.answer: Affiliate ID Cards are available for spouses and domestic partners of graduate students that allow them to access Carnegie Mellon’s campus. These cards are available through The HUB to spouses and partners of graduate students who are enrolled for the current academic year in a full-time graduate degree program.

qa_list.question: What is the validity period of Affiliate ID Cards?
qa_list.answer: The card is valid for one year.

qa_list.question: Where can students and affiliates find more information about student and affiliate ID cards?
qa_list.answer: For more information about student and affiliate ID cards, please visit: http://www.cmu.edu/idplus/idcards/sponsored.html.

qa_list.question: What is the source of the text?
qa_list.answer: The text is from the LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook, Page 23.

qa_list.question: What resources are available for new mothers on campus and in the Pittsburgh area according to the resource page maintained by the Graduate Student Assembly?
qa_list.answer: The resource page maintains links to resources around campus and the Pittsburgh area for new mothers.

qa_list.question: What is the URL of the resource page maintained by the Graduate Student Assembly?
qa_list.answer: https://www.cmu.edu/stugov/gsa/Resources-for-Graduate-Students/index.html

qa_list.question: What is The Student Parent Association according to the resource page maintained by the Graduate Student Assembly?
qa_list.answer: The Student Parent Association is a resource available for spouses, domestic partners and families of graduate students.

qa_list.question: Who can access new mother rooms on campus?
qa_list.answer: New mother rooms are available for spouses, domestic partners and families of graduate students.

qa_list.question: What benefits does Carnegie Mellon extend to domestic partners of students?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon extends certain benefits to domestic partners of students. Eligible students may elect benefits for their domestic partners through the registration process orchestrated by the Office of the Dean of Students, Warner Hall, room 321.

qa_list.question: Where can eligible students find information about available benefits and registration instructions?
qa_list.answer: Information regarding the benefits available for domestic partners, eligibility for domestic partner benefits, registration instructions and forms can be located at: https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/dean/domestic-partner/index.html.

qa_list.question: Does Carnegie Mellon offer housing to graduate students?
qa_list.answer: The university does not currently offer housing to graduate students.

qa_list.question: What information can the Office of Housing and Dining Services provide for graduate students seeking off-campus housing?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Housing and Dining Services provides community housing information to assist graduate students who are seeking housing in the communities surrounding the university, including information on the legal aspects of renting an apartment, moving checklists and the off-campus housing database.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about dining services offered by Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Information about dining locations, hours of operation, graduate student dining plans forms, nutritional information, and daily specials for dining locations can be found on the Dining Service website at https://www.cmu.edu/dining/

qa_list.question: What kind of transportation services does Carnegie Mellon offer?
qa_list.answer: Dining services and operations are offered through the Office of Housing and Dining Services, which operates dining locations open in and around campus. These locations offer flexible hours with options from the early morning through late night.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about parking at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Information about parking and transportation services offered by Carnegie Mellon can be found on the Dining Service website at https://www.cmu.edu/housing/our-communities/index.html.

qa_list.question: What kind of dining options are available for students at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Dining services and operations are offered through the Office of Housing and Dining Services, which operates dining locations open in and around campus. These locations offer flexible hours with options from the early morning through late night.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for Carnegie Mellon's Dining Service website?
qa_list.answer: The URL for Carnegie Mellon's Dining Service website is https://www.cmu.edu/dining/

qa_list.question: Where can graduate students find information about dining services and operations at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students can find information about dining services and operations through the Office of Housing and Dining Services. The office operates various dining locations open in and around campus, offering flexible hours with options from early morning to late night.

qa_list.question: What types of parking are available on CMU's campus?
qa_list.answer: There are three types of parking available on CMU's campus: permit parking, metered parking, and hourly garage parking. Permit parking is limited and has varying rates, while metered parking requires a valid university ID to park at an expired meter.

qa_list.question: What transportation services does CMU offer for graduate students?
qa_list.answer: CMU offers shuttle and escort services that operate in the evening/overnight, providing free transportation from campus to within a block of your home in Oakland, Squirrel Hill, and Shadyside neighborhoods as well as university sites outside the main campus.

qa_list.question: Where can graduate students find information about parking policies at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students can find information about parking policies and availability on the Parking and Transportation Services site. The office is located in the East Campus Garage (by Forbes Avenue entrance).

qa_list.question: What does the LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook provide?
qa_list.answer: The LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook provides information for graduate students, including details about dining services and operations, parking policies, transportation options, nutritional information, daily specials for dining locations, and more.

qa_list.question: What is the location of Parking and Transportation Services office at CMU?
qa_list.answer: The Parking and Transportation Services office is located in the East Campus Garage (by Forbes Avenue entrance) on CMU's campus.

qa_list.question: What are the hours of operation for dining locations at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Dining locations at CMU offer flexible hours with options from early morning through late night. The specific hours can be found on the Dining Services website.

qa_list.question: How can graduate students check their parking permit status?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students can check their parking permit status by visiting the Parking and Transportation Services site. The office is located in the East Campus Garage (by Forbes Avenue entrance).

qa_list.question: What are the rates for parking permits at CMU?
qa_list.answer: The varying permit rates can be found on the Parking and Transportation Services site. Permit parking is limited, so it's important to check the website regularly.

qa_list.question: What happens if a graduate student parks in a permit area without a permit or at an expired meter?
qa_list.answer: Parking and Transportation Services will ticket any car parked in a permit area without a permit or at an expired meter. The city also monitors the metered parking along Margaret Morrison, Frew, and Tech Streets.

qa_list.question: What services does Tartan Ink offer?
qa_list.answer: Tartan Ink offers UPS services, copy centers, printing and mailing services, postal services.

qa_list.question: Where is the Jared L. Cohon University Center located?
qa_list.answer: The Jared L. Cohon University Center is a centerpiece of the campus that provides a space for special events, physical fitness, student organizations and various activities, as well as accommodating retail and dining services.

qa_list.question: What are the functions of the Jared L. Cohon University Center?
qa_list.answer: The Jared L. Cohon University Center is a place for students to interact, get involved and enjoy new experiences as it accommodates retail and dining services.

qa_list.question: What kind of information can be found on the Office of Tartan Ink website?
qa_list.answer: Information regarding up-to-date shuttle and escort schedules, pick-up/drop-off locations, routes and usage policies can be found at: https://www.cmu.edu/parking/transport/escort.html.

qa_list.question: Where is the University Center Information Desk located?
qa_list.answer: The University Center Information Desk (first floor of the Cohon Center next to Wean Commons and Kirr Commons) is the location if you want to know about upcoming campus events or have questions about Carnegie Mellon in general.

qa_list.question: What services does the University Center Information Desk provide?
qa_list.answer: The University Center Information Desk provides information about campus events, sells postage stamps, makes copies, sends faxes, distributes campus maps, manages a lost & found, and has information brochures about Pittsburgh and the campus.

qa_list.question: What are the functions of the Wright-Rogal Chapel?
qa_list.answer: The Wright-Rogal Chapel is located in the Jared L. Cohon University Center, but its function is not specified in the given text.

qa_list.question: What kind of facilities are available at Athletic/Fitness Facilities?
qa_list.answer: The type and number of facilities available at Athletic/Fitness Facilities are not specified in the given text.

qa_list.question: What facilities does Carnegie Mellon offer for athletics?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon offers intercollegiate athletics, intramural sports, physical education classes and club sports.

qa_list.question: Where are the administrative offices of the Athletics Department located?
qa_list.answer: The administrative offices of the Athletics Department are located in the Cohon University Fitness Center.

qa_list.question: What recreational facilities does the University Center have?
qa_list.answer: The University Center has an eight-lane pool, racquetball and squash courts, aerobics room, fitness center and gym for basketball and volleyball.

qa_list.question: What is scheduled to happen with Skibo Gym and the Highmark Center?
qa_list.answer: Renovations are scheduled for Skibo Gym and the new Highmark Center for Health, Wellness, and Athletics.

qa_list.question: What kind of classes does the Athletics Department offer in the University Center?
qa_list.answer: The Athletics Department offers aerobics classes in the University Center as well as occasional workshops and instruction related to fitness and health.

qa_list.question: Who can participate in intramural sports at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Both participants and spectators can enjoy intercollegiate athletics, intramural sports, physical education classes and club sports.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Cohon University Fitness Center?
qa_list.answer: The Cohon University Fitness Center serves as the administrative offices for the Athletics Department.

qa_list.question: How many lanes does the pool in the University Center have?
qa_list.answer: The University Center’s recreational facilities include an eight-lane pool.

qa_list.question: What kind of sports can be played in the gym for basketball and volleyball at the University Center?
qa_list.answer: Basketball and volleyball games can be held in the gym at the University Center.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the Office of the Dean of Students at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Office of the Dean of Students provides central leadership for the meta-curricular experience at Carnegie Mellon, including coordination of student support. It also manages the Student Emergency Support Funding process and enrollment information for Domestic Partner Registration and Childbirth/Maternity Accommodations.

qa_list.question: Who leads the Division of Student Affairs at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Vice President of Student Affairs and Dean of Students Gina Casalegno leads the Division of Student Affairs, which includes various offices and departments.

qa_list.question: What types of support funding are available for enrolled students at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: There are three forms of support funding for enrolled students: emergency student loans, maternity loans, and the Tartan Emergency Support Fund. These funds are made available through generous gifts from alumni and friends of the university as well as support from student organizations.

qa_list.question: What is not eligible for Student Emergency Support funding at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Tuition costs are not eligible for Student Emergency Support funding.

qa_list.question: How do students receive additional information about the various types of funding during a consultation meeting with a member of the Dean of Students team?
qa_list.answer: During a consultation meeting with a member of the Dean of Students team, students will be provided with additional information about the various types of funding.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Office of the Dean of Students at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Office of the Dean of Students provides central leadership for the meta-curricular experience at Carnegie Mellon, including coordination of student support.

qa_list.question: What is included in the enrollment information provided by the Office of the Dean of Students?
qa_list.answer: The Office of the Dean of Students provides enrollment information for Domestic Partner Registration and Childbirth/Maternity Accommodations.

qa_list.question: What is the role of student organizations, Undergraduate Student Senate, and Graduate Student Assembly in providing support at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Student organizations, Undergraduate Student Senate, and Graduate Student Assembly provide support for various initiatives at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: How does the Office of the Dean of Students collaborate with other offices and organizations?
qa_list.answer: The Office of the Dean of Students partners with many other offices and organizations, such as the Graduate Student Assembly, to support the holistic graduate student educational experience.

qa_list.question: What is the main purpose of the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The main purpose of the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion at Carnegie Mellon University is to cultivate a strong, diverse and inclusive community capable of living out the values of the university and advancing research, creativity, learning and development that changes the world.

qa_list.question: What types of initiatives does the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion offer?
qa_list.answer: The Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion offers various initiatives such as first generation/first in family to attend college programs, LGBTQ+ Initiatives, race and ethnically focused programs like Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series (SOC) and PhD SOC Network, women’s empowerment programs including Graduate Women’s Gatherings (GWGs), and transgender and non-binary student programs.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion in enhancing an inclusive and transformative student experience?
qa_list.answer: The Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion plays a crucial role in enhancing an inclusive and transformative student experience by offering resources that focus on dimensions such as access, success, campus climate, and intergroup dialogue.

qa_list.question: What types of programs does the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion support specifically?
qa_list.answer: The Center supports historically underrepresented students and those who are first in their family to attend college. It also supports specific groups such as LGBTQ+, race-focused, women’s empowerment, and transgender/non-binary student programs.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Graduate Women's Gatherings (GWGs) initiative?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of Graduate Women's Gatherings (GWGs) initiative is to empower women and provide them with a supportive community at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: What are the types of student activities offered by the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion?
qa_list.answer: The Center offers various student activities such as first generation/first in family to attend college programs, LGBTQ+ Initiatives, race and ethnically focused programs like Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series (SOC) and PhD SOC Network, women’s empowerment programs including Graduate Women’s Gatherings (GWGs), and transgender and non-binary student programs.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion in connecting students with resources?
qa_list.answer: The Center plays a significant role in connecting students with various resources that enhance their academic, social and personal growth. It offers initiatives such as first generation/first in family to attend college programs, LGBTQ+ Initiatives, race and ethnically focused programs like Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series (SOC) and PhD SOC Network, women’s empowerment programs including Graduate Women’s Gatherings (GWGs), and transgender and non-binary student programs.

qa_list.question: What is the significance of Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series (SOC) and PhD SOC Network?
qa_list.answer: Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series (SOC) and PhD SOC Network are significant initiatives that provide a platform for graduate students from diverse backgrounds to connect, share experiences, and support each other in their academic journey.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion in fostering an inclusive campus climate?
qa_list.answer: The Center plays a vital role in fostering an inclusive campus climate by offering resources and initiatives that promote understanding, respect, and appreciation among students from diverse backgrounds.

qa_list.question: What are some initiatives that support LGBTQ+ and non-binary students at the university?
qa_list.answer: The university offers Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series (SOC) and PhD SOC Network for race and ethnically focused programs, as well as Transgender and non-binary student programs.

qa_list.question: Who is the point person in the division for graduate student resources and concerns?
qa_list.answer: Holly Hippensteel, Associate Vice President for Community Standards & Diversity Initiatives serves as the point person in the division for graduate student resources and concerns.

qa_list.question: Where can graduate students find enrollment information for Domestic Partner Registration?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students will find the enrollment information for Domestic Partner Registration in the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs and on the website.

qa_list.question: What is the Emergency Student Loan (ESLs) process managed by?
qa_list.answer: The Emergency Student Loan service is made available through the generous gifts of alumni and friends of the university. The Office of the Dean of Student Affairs also manages the ESLs process.

qa_list.question: What are the terms for repayment of an Emergency Student Loan?
qa_list.answer: The Emergency Student Loan is an interest-free, emergency-based loan repayable within 30 days.

qa_list.question: Who provides consultation and support for questions and issues of Academic Integrity at the university?
qa_list.answer: The Office of the Dean of Student Affairs also provides consultation, support, resources and follow-up on questions and issues of Academic Integrity: www.cmu.edu/academic-integrity.

qa_list.question: What kind of support is provided for graduate students who are or will be teaching?
qa_list.answer: Support for graduate students who are or will be teaching is provided in many departments and centrally by the Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation.

qa_list.question: What does the Eberly Center offer to current and prospective teaching assistants?
qa_list.answer: The Eberly Center offers activities for current and prospective teaching assistants as well as any graduate students who wish to prepare for the teaching component of an academic career.

qa_list.question: What does the Eberly Center do in addition to supporting individual graduate students?
qa_list.answer: The Center also assists departments in creating and conducting programs to meet the specific needs of students in their programs.

qa_list.question: What is the main topic of this text?
qa_list.answer: The Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation and its programs to support graduate students as teaching assistants or instructors.

qa_list.question: Where can one find more information about the services offered by the Eberly Center?
qa_list.answer: More specific information about the Eberly Center's offerings for graduate student support is found in the LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook, Page 29.

qa_list.question: What are the two main programs offered by the Eberly Center?
qa_list.answer: The two primary programs provided by the Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation are campus-wide Graduate Student Instructor Orientation events and their Future Faculty Program.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Future Faculty Program?
qa_list.answer: The primary goal of the Future Faculty Program at the Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation is to disseminate evidence-based teaching strategies in ways that are accessible and actionable.

qa_list.question: What kind of support does the Eberly Center offer to departments?
qa_list.answer: The Eberly Center assists departments by creating and conducting customized programs tailored specifically for their graduate student instructors' needs.

qa_list.question: What is A.3.3 in the text?
qa_list.answer: A.3.3 refers to a specific section or guideline within the Eberly Center's offerings for teaching assistance and instructional support.

qa_list.question: Why does the Eberly Center focus on graduate students as teaching assistants?
qa_list.answer: The Eberly Center is dedicated to supporting graduate students in their roles as teaching assistants or instructors because they are often involved in educational activities during their time at Carnegie Mellon University and may become future faculty members elsewhere.

qa_list.question: What does the text suggest about the Eberly Center's approach to teaching strategies?
qa_list.answer: The text implies that the Eberly Center uses evidence-based teaching methods, making them accessible and actionable for participants.

qa_list.question: What is the significance of 'about questions' in this context?
qa_list.answer: In the context of the Eberly Center's programs and services, 'about questions' likely refer to the types of queries that graduate students or instructors might encounter when teaching others. These could include questions about course content, instructional strategies, student engagement techniques, etc.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Office of International Education (OIE) at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Office of International Education (OIE) serves as a liaison to the university for all non-immigrant students and scholars, provides advisement on personal, immigration, study abroad, academic, and social matters, offers international education statistics, posts pertinent information through email and its website, and conducts orientation and pre-departure programs.

qa_list.question: What services does the Office of International Education (OIE) provide?
qa_list.answer: The OIE provides various services including advising on personal, immigration, study abroad, academic matters, social and acculturation international career workshops, tax workshops, cross-cultural and immigration workshops; conducts orientation and pre-departure programs.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Veterans & Military Community website at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Veterans & Military Community website provides information on applying for veteran education benefits, campus services, veteran’s groups at CMU, and non-educational resources.

qa_list.question: Who is the target audience of the Veterans & Military Community website?
qa_list.answer: The target audience of the Veterans & Military Community website are military veterans who are part of the Carnegie Mellon University community.

qa_list.question: What kind of programs does the Office of International Education (OIE) present?
qa_list.answer: The OIE presents programs of interest such as international education and statistics on international students in the United States, cross-cultural workshops, immigration workshops, tax workshops, and international career workshops.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook mentioned on Page 30?
qa_list.answer: The LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook provides information for graduate students, including those who are military veterans.

qa_list.question: What is the relationship between Carnegie Mellon University and international students?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon hosts international graduate and undergraduate students from more than 90 countries, with the Office of International Education (OIE) serving as a liaison to the university for all non-immigrant students and scholars.

qa_list.question: What is the role of OIE in providing information to international students?
qa_list.answer: The Office of International Education (OIE) provides pertinent information through email and its website, conducts orientation and pre-departure programs, and posts study abroad opportunities and advisement.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Veterans & Military Community website at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Veterans & Military Community website provides information on applying for veteran education benefits, campus services, veteran’s groups at CMU, and non-educational resources.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for the Policy Against Retaliation at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/whistleblower.html

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) provides a private and confidential setting for students to discuss academic and personal concerns. An initial consultation can help clarify the nature of the concern, provide immediate support, and explore further options if needed.

qa_list.question: What are some additional resources that Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) may refer a student to?
qa_list.answer: Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) may refer students to other resources at Carnegie Mellon University or within the larger Pittsburgh community.

qa_list.question: What types of workshops and group sessions does Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) offer?
qa_list.answer: Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) offers mental health workshops and group sessions.

qa_list.question: Where can a student find more information about the Key Offices for Health, Wellness & Safety at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: A student can find more information about the Key Offices for Health, Wellness & Safety by visiting https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/whistleblower.html

qa_list.question: What is the URL of the LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook where more information about Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) can be found?
qa_list.answer: The LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook, which contains more information about Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS), is available at Page 31.

qa_list.question: What does CaPS stand for in the context of Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: In the context of Carnegie Mellon University, CaPS stands for Counseling & Psychological Services.

qa_list.question: Where can a student find more information about the Policy Against Retaliation at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: A student can find more information about the Policy Against Retaliation by visiting https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/whistleblower.html

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Key Offices for Health, Wellness & Safety at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the Key Offices for Health, Wellness & Safety at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide resources and support for students' health, well-being, and safety.

qa_list.question: What services are provided by University Health Services (UHS) at CMU?
qa_list.answer: University Health Services (UHS) provides general medical care, allergy injections, first aid, gynecological care and contraception as well as on-site pharmaceutricals.

qa_list.question: How can students make appointments at UHS?
qa_list.answer: Students can make appointments by visiting in person or calling 412-268-2922.

qa_list.question: What is the responsibility of students regarding fees for prescription medications, laboratory tests, diagnostic procedures and referral to emergency room or specialists?
qa_list.answer: Students are responsible for fees for prescription medications, laboratory tests, diagnostic procedures and referral to emergency room or specialists.

qa_list.question: What kind of health issues can students address with UHS's registered dietician and health promotion specialists?
qa_list.answer: Students can address nutrition, drug and alcohol, and other healthy lifestyle issues with UHS's registered dietician and health promotion specialists.

qa_list.question: How can students make appointments at the Student Health Insurance Program?
qa_list.answer: Students can make appointments by visiting UHS’s website, walk-in or calling 412-268-2157.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Student Health Insurance Program?
qa_list.answer: The Student Health Insurance Program administers a high level of coverage in a wide network of health care providers and hospitals.

qa_list.question: Where can students find the most up-to-date information about public health safety requirements?
qa_list.answer: Students should visit www.cmu.edu/coronavirus/ for the most up to date information about public health safety requirements.

qa_list.question: What is Campus Wellness at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Campus Wellness at Carnegie Mellon University provides individual and collective well-being resources for students, faculty, and staff.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about Campus Wellness?
qa_list.answer: Students can find more information about Campus Wellness at https://www.cmu.edu/wellness/

doc_text:
ry, Mellon Library, and the Sorrells Library with the combined mission of providing access and help to graduate students in finding the information needed, teaching graduate students to evaluate available information and use reliable sources. The libraries’ digital resources and services, including off-campus/ wireless access to databases and e-journals, offer online access. There are also two neighboring libraries open to Carnegie Mellon graduate students: Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh and University of Pittsburgh Libraries. Visit the University Libraries website for information about all mentioned library locations and hours, on-line resources, and FAQ’s.
6.9 Computing Services
Computing Services is located in Cyert Hall – Room 285. Computing Services develops, maintains, and supports the computing infrastructure for Carnegie Mellon students, faculty members and staff members. This includes the campus wired and wireless networks, public computer labs or “clusters,” cable television and telephone services, computing related documentation and support through the Help Center. In addition, Computing Services provides standard classroom technologies for over 100 lecture halls, classrooms, and seminar rooms across campus. The website contains addition information regarding The Help Center hours, location and contact information, computing cluster hours and location, the Carnegie Mellon web portal, computing security and policies and guidelines. Students can email the Help Center at it- help@cmu.edu or call 412-268-4357 (HELP) with questions and for assistance.
6.10 Family and Dependents Resources
The Graduate Student Assembly website maintains a resource page for spouses, domestic partners and families of graduate students: https://www.cmu.edu/stugov/gsa/Resources-for- Graduate-Students/index.html , including The Student Parent Association, new mother rooms, and links to resources around campus and the Pittsburgh area.
Affiliate ID Cards are available for spouses and domestic partners of graduate students that allow them to access Carnegie Mellon’s campus. These cards are available through The HUB to spouses and partners of graduate students who are enrolled for the current academic year in a full-time graduate degree program. The card is valid for one year. For more information about student and affiliate ID cards, please visit: http://www.cmu.edu/idplus/idcards/sponsored.html.

6.11 Domestic Partner Registration
Carnegie Mellon extends certain benefits to domestic partners of students. Eligible students may elect benefits for their domestic partners through the registration process orchestrated by the Office of the Dean of Students, Warner Hall, room 321. Information regarding the benefits avail-able for domestic partners, eligibility for domestic partner benefits, registration instructions and forms can be located at: https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/dean/domestic- partner/index.html.
6.12 Housing
The university does not currently offer housing to graduate students. The Office of Housing and Dining Services does provide community housing information to assist graduate students who are seeking housing in the communities surrounding the university, including information on the legal aspects of renting an apartment, moving checklists and the off-campus housing database. This https://www.cmu.edu/housing/our- communities/index.html.
information can be
located at:
6.13 Dining
www.cmu.edu/dining/ Dining services and operations are offered through the Office of Housing and Dining Services. The office operates dining locations open in and around campus. These locations offer flexible hours with options from the early morning through late night. The Dining Service website contains information about dining locations, hours of operation, graduate student dining plans forms, nutritional information, and daily specials for dining locations.’
6.14 Parking and Transportation
www.cmu.edu/parking/ Graduate students will find information about parking and availability, parking policies, transportation options and Port Authority Transit usage with a valid university ID on the Parking and Transportation Services site. The Parking and Transportation Services office is located in the East Campus Garage (by Forbes Avenue entrance). There is limited parking on campus and the varying permit rates can be found on the website. All parking areas of campus are either by permit, metered or by the hour in the garage. Parking and Transportation Services will ticket any car parked in a permit area without a permit or at an expired meter. The city monitors the metered parking along Margaret Morrison, Frew and Tech Streets and will ticket at expired meters as well.
The university offers shuttle and escort services operates in the evening/overnight and provides free transportation from campus to within a block of your home in the Oakland, Squirrel Hill, and Shadyside neighborhoods, as well as to university sites located outside of the main campus.
LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook
Page 24


The Escort Service offers vehicle routes within a radius of campus between 6:30 pm-4:15 am daily. You must show your CMU ID to board.
Information regarding up-to-date shuttle and escort schedules, pick-up/drop-off locations, routes and usage policies can be found at: https://www.cmu.edu/parking/transport/escort.html .
6.15 Copying, Printing and Mailing Services
Tartan Ink offers community members easy access to UPS services, copy centers, printing and mailing services, and postal services. Tartan Ink is located on the Lower Level of the Cohon University Center. More information regarding these services, business hours, locations and contact Ink website at: https://www.cmu.edu/tartanink/aboutus/index.html.

6.16 University Center
www.cmu.edu/university-center The Jared L. Cohon University Center is a centerpiece of the campus that provides a space for special events, physical fitness, student organizations and various activities, as well as accommodating retail and dining services. As the campus crossroads, the University Center functions as a place for students to interact, get involved and enjoy new experiences. Visit the University Center website for information about campus eateries, ATMs and PNC Bank, fitness rooms and schedules, retail stores, scheduling University Center space, the public prayer room, student organizations, and the Wright-Rogal Chapel.
The University Center Information Desk (first floor of the Cohon Center next to Wean Commons and Kirr Commons) is the location if you want to know about upcoming campus events or have questions about Carnegie Mellon in general, call the Information Desk at 412- 268-2107. The Information Desk not only provides information about campus events, but also sells postage stamps, makes copies, sends faxes, distributes campus maps, manages a lost & found, and has information brochures about Pittsburgh and the campus.
6.17 Athletic/Fitness Facilities
www.cmu.edu/athletics For the participant or the spectator, Carnegie Mellon offers intercollegiate athletics, intramural sports, physical education classes and club sports. The Athletics Department also offers aerobics classes in the University Center as well as occasional workshops and instruction related to fitness and health. The administrative offices are located in the Cohon University Fitness Center.
The University Center’s recreational facilities include an eight-lane pool, racquetball and squash courts, aerobics room, fitness center and gym for basketball and volleyball. With renovations to Skibo Gym and the new Highmark Center for Health, Wellness, and Athletics scheduled for
LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook
Page 25


completion in 2024, the strength and conditioning facility has been temporarily placed on the lawn next to the outdoor basketball court close to the Donner locker rooms, Gesling Stadium, and Weigand Gymnasium. All users must present a valid CMU ID to use these facilities.
6.18 CMU Alert
www.cmu.edu/alert CMU Alert sends voice and/or text messages to registered phones in the event of a campus emergency that threatens public safety or during tests of the system in the spring and fall semesters. Students are automatically registered for CMU-Alert using the current contact (SIO): information https://www.cmu.edu/hub/sio/about.html.

A.1
Key Offices for Graduate Student Support
A.1.1
Office of Graduate & Postdoc Affairs
www.cmu.edu/graduate; grad-ed@cmu.edu The Office of Graduate & Postdoc Affairs provides central support for all master’s and doctoral students, as well as academic programs, with a focus on supporting graduate student success at Carnegie Mellon.
Examples of resources offered through the Office of Graduate & Postdoc Affairs include but are not limited to:
Website with university resources, contact information for CMU programs and services, calendar of events related to graduate students
Bi-monthly newsletter to all graduate students with information on activities, resources, and opportunities
Professional Development Seminars and Workshops • GSA/Provost Conference Funding Grants • GSA/Provost Small Research Grants (GuSH) • Consultations on issues related to the graduate student experience
The Office of Graduate & Postdoc Affairs also works with the colleges and departments by informing and assisting in developing policy and procedures relevant to graduate students and working with departments on issues related to graduate students. Additionally, we
LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook
Page 26


partner with many other offices and organizations, such as the Graduate Student Assembly, to support the holistic graduate student educational experience.
A.2
Office of the Dean of Students
https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/dean
The Office of the Dean of Students provides central leadership of the meta curricular experience at Carnegie Mellon including the coordination of student support. Vice President of Student Affairs and Dean of Students Gina Casalegno leads the Division of Student Affairs which includes the offices and departments listed below (not an exhaustive list).
Graduate students will find the enrollment information for Domestic Partner Registration and Childbirth/Maternity Accommodations in the Office of the Dean of Students or on their website. This Office also manages the Student Emergency Support Funding process. There are three forms of support funding for enrolled students: emergency student loans, maternity loans, and the Tartan Emergency Support Fund. These funds are made available through generous gifts of alumni and friends of the university as well as support from student organizations, Undergraduate Student Senate and the Graduate Student Assembly. Students will be provided with additional information about the various types of funding during a consultation meeting with a member of the Dean of Students team. Tuition costs are not eligible for Student Emergency Support funding.
Additional resources for graduate students include College Liaisons and the Student Support Resources team. College Liaisons are senior members of the Division of Student Affairs who work with departments and colleges addressing student concerns across a wide range of issues. College Liaisons are identified on the student SIO page in the Important Contacts list. The Student Support Resources team offers an additional level of support for students who are navigating any of a wide range of life events. Student Support Resources staff members work in partnership with campus and community resources to provide coordination of care and support appropriate to each student’s situation.
The Division of Student Affairs includes (not an exhaustive list):
Athletics, Physical Education and Recreation • Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC) • Center for Student Diversity and Inclusion • Cohon University Center • Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) • Dining Services • Office of Community Standards and Integrity (OCSI) • Office of Student Leadership, Involvement, and Civic Engagement (SLICE) • University Health Services (UHS)
LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook

Wellness Initiatives
A.3 Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion
https://www.cmu.edu/student-diversity Diversity and inclusion have a singular place among the values of Carnegie Mellon University. The Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion actively cultivates a strong, diverse and inclusive community capable of living out these values and advancing research, creativity, learning and development that changes the world.
The Center offers resources to enhance an inclusive and transformative student experience in dimensions such as access, success, campus climate and intergroup dialogue. Additionally, the Center supports and connects historically underrepresented students and those who are first in their family to attend college in a setting where students’ differences and talents are appreciated and reinforced, both at the graduate and undergraduate level. Initiatives coordinated by the Center include, but are not limited to:
First generation/first in family to attend college programs • LGBTQ+ Initiatives • Race and ethnically focused programs, including Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series (SOC) and PhD SOC Network
Women’s empowerment programs, including Graduate Women’s Gatherings (GWGs) • Transgender and non-binary student programs
Student Activities/Student Life.
Holly Hippensteel, Associate Vice President for Community Standards & Diversity Initiatives, serves as the point person in the division for graduate student resources and concerns. Graduate students will find the enrollment information for Domestic Partner Registration in the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs and on the website. The Office of the Dean of Student Affairs also manages the Emergency Student Loan (ESLs) process. The Emergency Student Loan service is made available through the generous gifts of alumni and friends of the university. The Emergency Student Loan is an interest-free, emergency-based loan repayable within 30 days. Loans are available to enrolled students for academic supplies, medication, food, or other expenses not able to be met due to unforeseeable circumstances. The Office of the Dean of Student Affairs also provides consultation, support, resources and follow-up on questions and issues of Academic Integrity: www.cmu.edu/academic-integrity.
Support for graduate students who are or will be teaching is provided in many departments and centrally by the Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation. The Eberly Center offers activities for current and prospective teaching assistants as well as any graduate students who wish to prepare for the teaching component of an academic career. The Center also assists departments in creating and conducting programs to meet the specific needs of students in their programs. Specific information about Eberly Center

A.3.1
Carnegie Mellon Ethics Hotline
https://www.cmu.edu/hr/resources/ethics-hotline.html
The health, safety and well-being of the university community are top priorities at Carnegie Mellon University. CMU provides a hotline that all members of the university community should use to confidentially report suspected unethical or illegal activity, violations of university policy, or violations of law.
Students, faculty, and staff can anonymously file a report by calling toll-free, within the United States, Guam, Puerto Rico and Canada: 844-587-0793 or by visiting NAVEX EthicsPoint’s secure reporting form online. All submissions will be reported to appropriate university personnel. The EthicsPoint hotline is NOT an emergency service. For emergencies, call University Police at 412-268-2323. For off-campus emergencies, call 9-1-1.
A.3.2
Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities
https://www.cmu.edu/hr/resources/hr-partners/disability.html The Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University has a continued mission to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience. We work to ensure that qualified individuals receive reasonable accommodations as guaranteed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973. Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin the process through Disability Resources' secure online portal or email access@andrew.cmu.edu interactive accommodation Process. Students with physical, sensory, cognitive, or emotional disabilities are encouraged to self-identify with the Office of Disability Resources and request needed to accommodations. Any access@andrew.cmu.edu, or call (412) 268- 6121.

A.3.3
Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation
https://www.cmu.edu/teaching We offer a wide variety of confidential, consultation services and professional development programs to support graduate students as teaching assistants or instructors of record during their time at Carnegie Mellon University and as future faculty members at other institutions. Regardless of one's current or future teaching context and duties, our goal is to disseminate evidence-based teaching strategies in ways that are accessible and actionable. Programs and services include campus-wide Graduate Student Instructor Orientation events and our Future Faculty Program, both of which are designed to help participants be effective and efficient in their teaching roles. The Eberly Center also assists departments in creating and conducting customized programs to meet the specific needs of their graduate student instructors. A.3.4 Graduate Student Assembly
https://www.cmu.edu/stugov/gsa/index.html The Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) is the branch of Carnegie Mellon Student Government that represents, and advocates for the diverse interests of all graduate students at CMU. GSA is composed of representatives from the different graduate programs and departments who want to improve the graduate student experience at the different levels of the university. GSA is funded by the Student Activities Fee from all graduate students. GSA passes legislation, allocates student activities funding, advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C. on behalf of graduate student issues and needs, and otherwise acts on behalf of all graduate student interests. Our recent accomplishments are a testament to GSA making a difference, and steps plan. the https://www.cmu.edu/stugov/gsa/about-the-gsa/strategic-plan.html.

GSA offers an expanding suite of social programming on and off-campus to bring graduate students from different departments together and build a sense of community. GSA is the host of the Graduate Student Lounge on the 3rd floor of the Cohon University Center- a great place to study or meet up with friends. GSA also maintains a website of graduate student resources on and off-campus. Through GSA’s continued funding for professional development and research conferences, the GSA/Provost Conference Funding Program and GSA/Provost GuSH Research Grants are able to run, as managed by the Graduate Education Office. As we move forward, GSA will continue to rely on your feedback to improve the graduate student experience at CMU. Feel free to contact us at gsa@andrew.cmu.edu to get involved, stop by our office in the Cohon University Center Room 304, or become a representative for your department.
A.3.5 Office of International Education (OIE)
https://www.cmu.edu/oie/ Carnegie Mellon hosts international graduate and undergraduate students who come from more than 90 countries. The Office of International Education (OIE) is the liaison to the University for all non-immigrant students and scholars, as well the repository for study abroad opportunities and advisement. OIE provides many services including: advising on personal, immigration, study abroad, academic, and social and acculturation international career workshops, tax workshops, and cross-cultural and immigration workshops; international education and statistics on international students in the United States; posting pertinent information to students through email and the OIE website and conducting orientation and pre-departure programs.

A.3.6 https://www.cmu.edu/veterans/ Military veterans are a vital part of the Carnegie Mellon University community. Graduate students can find information on applying for veteran education benefits, campus services, veteran’s groups at CMU, and non-educational resources through the Veterans and Military Community website. There are also links and

A.3.7 https://www.cmu.edu/hr/resources/ethics-hotline.html
Carnegie Mellon Ethics Hotline
The health, safety and well-being of the university community are top priorities at Carnegie Mellon University. CMU provides a hotline that all members of the university community should use to confidentially report suspected unethical activity relating to areas below:
o Academic and Student Life o Bias Reporting o Environmental Health and Safety o Financial Matters o High-Risk Incident o Human Resource Related o Information Systems o Research o Threat of Business Interruption o Threat of Violence or Physical Harm o Title IX
Students, faculty, and staff can anonymously file a report by calling 877-700-7050 or visiting www.reportit.net(user name: tartans; password: plaid). All submissions are reported to appropriate university personnel. The hotline is NOT an emergency service. For emergencies, call University Police at 412-268-2323.
Policy Against Retaliation It is the policy of Carnegie Mellon University to protect from retaliation any individual who makes a good faith report of a suspected violation of any applicable law or regulation, university Policy or procedure, any contractual obligation of the university, and any report made pursuant to the Carnegie Mellon University Code of Business Ethics and Conduct.
Additional details regarding the Policy Against Retaliation are available at: https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/whistleblower.html
A.4
Key Offices for Health, Wellness & Safety
A.4.1
Counseling & Psychological Services
https://www.cmu.edu/counseling/ Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) affords the opportunity for students to talk privately about academic and personal concerns in a safe, confidential setting. An initial consultation at CaPS can help clarify the nature of the concern, provide immediate support, and explore further options if needed. These may include a referral for counseling within CaPS, to another resource at Carnegie Mellon, or to another resource within the larger Pittsburgh community. CaPS also provides workshops and group sessions on mental health
LTI PhD Graduate Student Handbook
Page 31


related topics specifically for graduate students on campus. CaPS services are provided at no cost. Appointments can be made in person, or by telephone at 412-268-2922.
A.4.2 Health Services
www.cmu.edu/HealthServices/ University Health Services (UHS) is staffed by physicians, advanced practice clinicians and registered nurses who provide general medical care, allergy injections, first aid, gynecological care and contraception as well as on-site pharmaceuticals. The CMU Student Insurance Plan covers most visit fees to see the physicians and advanced practice clinicians & nurse visits. Fees for prescription medications, laboratory tests, diagnostic procedures and referral to the emergency room or specialists are the student’s responsibility and students should review the UHS website and their insurance plan for detailed information about the university health insurance requirement and fees.
UHS also has a registered dietician and health promotion specialists on staff to assist students in addressing nutrition, drug and alcohol and other healthy lifestyle issues. In addition to providing direct health care, UHS administers the Student Health Insurance Program. The Student Health Insurance plan offers a high level of coverage in a wide network of health care providers and hospitals. Appointments can be made by visiting UHS’s website, walk-in, or by telephone, 412-268-2157.
Due to the changing nature of conditions and expectations surrounding public health safety requirements, please visit www.cmu.edu/coronavirus/ for the most up to date information.
